Found mortar taken to king reveals peasant girl's wisdom.

d: King and peasant vie in riddling questions and answers.
King and peasant: the plucked fowl.
a: The king gives riddling questions to a peasant, who always interprets them right. The king says that he will send the peasant a fowl which he shall pluck. The king gives the same questions to his courtiers, who cannot interpret them. They pay the peasant good money for the answers. Peasant tells king that he has plucked the fowl.

r: BP II 372; Chauvin VI 39 No. 207 n. 4.

r: *Wesselski Mdrchen 197; **De Vries FFC LXXIII; Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo II 389, *Boberg; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 122 No. 1358; Jewish: *Neuman; Arab: Azov 411f.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Batak: Voorhoeve 163 No. 169.
a: Apparently senseless remarks (or acts) interpreted figuratively prove wise.

d: Girl given enigmatic commands must do the opposite.
Three young men arrested tell who they are.
Arrested man tells who he is: before his father the great incline the head and give blood and money (barber).
Arrested man tells who he is: the hospitable fire of his father is sought (bean merchant).
Arrested man tells who he is: father throws himself into the ranks and holds them (weaver).
Arrested farmer tells who he is: one son is thief (priest), second beggar (teacher), and third murderer (doctor).
Riddling answers betray theft or adultery *BP I 198, II 361f.
Riddling answer betrays theft.
The full moon and the thirtieth of the month.
a: Prince sends servant to clever girl with a round tart, thirty cakes, and a capon, and asks her if it is full moon and the thirtieth of the month and if the cock has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month, and that the capon has gone to the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge's sake. She thus shows him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, and the capon.

d: Riddling answers betray adultery.
Enigmatic statement betrays incest.
Woman's question to her husband disguised as woman, how many men she had in one night.
a: This is properly understood as, how many helpers he had, and answered by lifting ten fingers.

d: Clever youth (maiden) answers king's inquiry in riddles.
King: What do you see?
a: Youth: One and a half men and a horse's head. (Himself, the legs of the king on horseback in the door, and the horse's head.)

d: King: Are you alone at home?
a: Youth: Not now; I see the half of two quadrupeds. (Two legs of the king and the forefeet of his horse.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: He is in the vineyard and is doing good and bad. (He prunes vines and sometimes cuts good and sometimes lets bad ones stay.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: Makes an evil greater. (Closes up a path; this causes another to be opened.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: Makes many out of few. (Sows grain.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: Makes better from good. (Hedges his field.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: Cuts wood which was burnt last year. (To pay old debts.)

d: King: What is your father doing?
a: Youth: He fences thorns with thorns. (Eggplant garden fenced with thorns.)

d: King: What is your brother doing?
r: *De Vries FFC LXXIII 128ff.; Wesselski Mtsnchslatein 120 No. 102; Missouri French: Carriire.
a: Youth: He hunts; he throws away what he catches and what he does not catch he carries with him. (Hunts for lice on his body.)

d: King: What is your brother doing?
a: Youth: He runs back and forth. (Plows.)

d: King: What is your brother doing?
a: Youth: He sits between heaven and earth. (In a tree.)

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Youth: She does for another what the latter cannot do for her. (Lays out a corpse.)

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Youth: She shows the light of the world to one who has not yet seen it. (Assists at a birth.)

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Youth: She is baking the bread we ate last week. (To pay back borrowed bread.)

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Youth: She cuts off the heads of the well to cure the sick. (Kills chickens to feed her sick mother.)

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Youth: She drives away the hungry and compels the filled to eat. (Drives away the hungry hens and stuffs the geese.)

d: King: What are your mother and father doing?
a: Girl: Mother is separating earth (being a midwife), and father is mixing earth (at a funeral).

d: King: What is your mother doing?
a: Girl: She has gone to turn one into two (to split peas).

d: King: What is your sister doing?
a: Youth: She is mourning last year's laughter. (Nurses child, the fruit of last year's love affair.)

d: King: What are you doing?
a: Youth: I boil those which come and go. (Beans which keep rising and falling in water.)

d: King: Where shall I tie my horse?
a: Maiden: Between summer and winter. (Between wagon and sleigh.)

d: Maiden (to king): The house has neither eyes nor ears.
a: (No child at window nor dog in yard to announce king's approach: he therefore finds her not dressed to receive him.)

d: Maiden (to king): Shall I feed you with loss or gain.
r: De Vries FFC LXXIII 254; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1465*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 877*.
a: (A slaughtered hen or milk.)

d: Girl to king: Should it (the flood) come I shall not come; should it not come, I shall come.
Other riddling answers.
Enigmatic conversation of king and peasant.
The four coins.
r: Ktshler-Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. Bolte) No. 8; Anderson FFC XLII 356 n. 1. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 921A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 921 I*; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Swahili): Steere 295.
a: (Focus.) King: What do you do with the four coins you earn? Peasant: First I eat (feed self); second I put out at interest (give my children); third I give back (pay debts); fourth I throw away (give my wife.)

d: King: Why did you not do it (marry so that sons could help you)?
a: Peasant: I did, but it was not God's will (I married three times but it was not God's will  to give me sons).

d: Riddling remarks of traveling companion interpreted by girl (man) at end of journey.
r: De Vries FFC LXXIII 43ff.; *Wesselski Mdrchen 197 No. 7; India: Thompson-Balys.

d: Man helps traveler and makes riddling remarks.
a: Gives him food, shares his coat in rain, and carries him over stream. Reproaches him with traveling without mother, house, or bridge (nourishment, shelter, or horse).

d: Traveler says he is going to the city to see what has become of the seed he sowed in the street.
r: Ktshler-Bolte I 197; Nouvelles de Sens No. 3.
a: (What has become of the girl he left in the city to await his return.)

d: Traveler says he is going to seek a hind that he saw in the woods ten years before.
a: (A maiden.)

d: Traveler says he must look after his net to see if it has taken fish.
a: (He has left his lady seven years before with a pledge of faithfulness. Net has taken fish lady has had lovers.)

d: One traveler to another: Let us carry each other and shorten the way.

d: One traveler to another: That field (uncut) is already harvested.
a: (Belongs to spendthrift who has already spent the money.)

d: One traveler to another (as they see corpse borne by): He is not entirely dead.
a: (Has left good property.)

d: One traveler to another (when asked how he crossed an unbridged stream): I cross on an ashen bridge.
r: Wesselski Mdrchen 197 No. 7; Nouvelles de Sens No. 8.
a: (Found a ford with an ashen staff.)

d: One traveler to another: Is this cup valuable or not?
a: (Is your daughter married or not?)

d: Boy says that travelers should catch the mares (walking sticks that are in the jungle).
King gives enigmatic order to minister.
Enigmatic letter of king must be explained on pain of death.
King: Show me a ruby eight for a pice, nectar eight for a pice, and a faithless creature worth one-eighth of a pice.
a: Minister: The lamp sells at eight for a pice and gives more light than any ruby; the water is the real nectar; and the dog is worthless and faithless lover because he follows anyone who feeds him.

d: Enigmatic counsels of a father.
r: Icelandic: Hervarar saga 36 39, 116 18, *Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys, (Kashmir): Knowles 243; Indonesia: De Vries's list No. 232; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 256 No. 200.
a: Taken literally bring trouble, but when properly interpreted are valuable.

d: Father-in-law gives daughter-in-law enigmatic permission to go home.
Father's counsel: walk not in sunshine from your house to your shop.
a: (Attend to business, rising early and retiring late.)

d: Father's counsel: let pilav be your daily food.
a: (Eat frugally.)

d: Father's counsel: marry a new wife every week.
a: (Do not see your wife too much.)

d: Father's counsel: on wishing to drink wine go to the vat and drink it.
a: (Stench in vat so great that desire for wine is turned to loathing.)

d: Father's counsel: if you want to gamble, then gamble with experienced gamblers.
a: (If you see how wretched professional gamblers are you will not want to gamble.)

d: Father's counsel: dress up the trunks of trees, cover the road.
a: (Plant the road with fruit trees and betel between the trees.)

d: Father's counsel: find treasure within a foot of the ground.

a: (Sons dig everywhere and thus loosen soil of vineyard, which becomes fruitful.)

d: Father's counsel: the four wells.
a: Three empty and one full (3 sons and father). Full one can fill the three empty but the three when full cannot fill the one when empty (sons when scattered will not support the father).

d: Father's counsel: dam up the outlets.
a: (Keep expenditures down not outlets of rice-field as son-in-law thinks).

d: Father's counsel: don't stay too late with a concubine, nor tell her any secret.
Always eat bread with "honey".
a: (Working diligently, your bread will be as sweet as honey.)

d: "Never greet anyone."
a: (Start your work the earliest, so that not you but others may greet you.)

d: "Always wear new shoes."
a: (Walk the fields bare-footed, wearing your shoes only when nearing the town.)

d: "Have a black look" (frown).
"Bite the ear" (do state affairs secretly).
"Take people by the locks" (use your influence to make people subservient to you).
"If you have to go to a prostitute, go early in the morning."
"When you go to the bazar, eat your morning meal first."
"A father should always check and never forgive; a mother should always forgive and never check."
"Do not plant a thorny tree."
Enigmatic advice: take only salt and water as food.
Extraordinary actions explained.
Man puts on shoes only when he wades river.
a: (He cannot see what he is walking on.)

d: Man uses umbrella under trees.
a: (To protect self from falling branches and bird droppings.)

d: Man cuts hooks for the revenge of his father (Hamlet).

d: "Love like wind in hot sun."
a: Husband offended but later learns wife's meaning.

d: Poison in nectar: wife who betrays husband to his enemies.
Nectar in poison: mistress who saves her lover.
Dogs in human shape: friends who seduce man's wife.
Donkey ruling a kingdom: king condemning man unjustly.

d: Enigmatic statement: the tank (pond) does not belong to you.

d: Enigmatic statement: the flocks are only rocks and grass.
a: (Else you would have given the beggar milk and curds.)

d: Enigmatic welcome of host.
a: Sounds very inhospitable but properly interpreted makes guests welcome.

d: Symbolic invitation to continued liberality.
Enigmatic counsels of relatives (other than father).

a: Gray younger brother asks well-preserved older brother for the secret of his good health. Answer: A measured mouth, a close purse, and a knot on the trouser's fly.

d: Enigmatic counsel: uproot old trees and plant new ones (dismiss old governors and appoint new).
Give coals orange color, let glimmer of gold appear like expanse of heaven, prepare two heads of darkness.

Wise carving of the fowl.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1580*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1580*; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI No. 1533*; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman; Filipino: Fansler MAFLS XII 63, 253, 351.

d: Symbolic interpretation of letters.

a: Soldier reproved for playing cards during church says that playing cards are his prayerbook and calendar. Ace: one God, one Faith, one Baptism; 2: old and new Testaments; 3: Trinity; 4: evangelists; 5: wise virgins; 6: days of creation; 7: sabbath; 8. Noah's family; 9: ungrateful lepers; 10: commandments; knave (jack): Judas; queen (of Sheba); king: God; 12 face cards: 12 months; etc.

d: Symbolic meaning of spiced and bitter tongue served at dinner.
Angel gives symbolic interpretation of value of work as well as of prayer.
a: Works and prays where monk can see him.

d: Symbolic interpretation of sin.
a: Priest drags heavy sack of sand behind him to show how men drag sin.

a: carried on in poetic obscure language.

Princess declares her love through sign language: not understood.
Is town too full of anchorites?
a: Saint entering holy town is sent cup full to brim of milk by its worldly-minded fakirs that he may know the town can hold no more anchorites. Saint floats a flower on milk and returns cup.

d: Symbolic interpretation of official robes.
Symbolic interpretation of points on a bishop's hat.
Youth asks for branch of tree; promised root.
a: (Branch = youngest daughter; root = eldest.)

d: Melons ripe and overripe analogous to girls ready for marriage.
r: Iraq: Ethel Stevens Folk Tales of Iraq (London, 1931) 60.

d: Sign message sent by girl to enamored prince; interpreted by prince's friend.
Chief asks another for cutting of yams to complete his yam patch (daughter in marriage).
a: Reply that seed yams for the year are shrivelled and old and it is too early for seedlings (his daughters are too young or too old).

d: Explanation of enigmatic phenomenon.
Explanation of phenomenon; a man who not only picks up wood but everything that lies in his path (a miser).
Explanation of phenomenon: large pond emptying itself into several smaller pools (man may spend without getting any return).
Symbolic interpretations of dreams.
Other symbolic interpretations.
Symbolic interpretation of chairs in heaven.
Symbolic interpretation of church and image therein.
Roots and branches of World-tree explained symbolically.
Symbolic interpretation of ineffectual thatching of house and building of fire in otherworld.
Symbolical interpretation of fight between one-legged bird and twelve-legged bird.
a: One-legged bird symbolizes innocence; twelve-legged bird, guilt.

d: The unsolved problem: enigmatic ending of tale.
Skillful companions create woman: to whom does she belong?

d: Skillful companions resuscitate girl: to whom does she belong?

d: What is swiftest?

a: Mother's eyes.

r: De Vries FFC LXXIII 87; BP II 358.

d: What is softest?

a: The hand. (In order to lie soft one places his hand between the head and the pillow.)

d: What is softest?

a: Mother's bosom.

d: Riddle: what is the fattest?

a: The earth.

d: Riddles of the superlative miscellaneous.

What is oldest?
a: God.

What four things are hardest to hold?

d: Riddle: what is the best fowl?

a: The goose, since it makes the cabbage sweet and the bed soft.

d: Riddle: what is best religion Christian or Mohammedan?
What is best religion Christian or Mohammedan?
a: They are equally good:  as both eyes are equally dear to you, so are both religions to God.

d: Riddle: what kind of work occupies most men?
What kind of work occupies most men?
a: Healing, for every sick man practices this.

d: Riddle: what is greatest?
What is greatest?
a: Fame.

d: What is the greatest?
a: A sense of shame.

d: What is the greatest?
a: Charity.

d: What is the greatest villainy?
a: Stealing.

d: What is moistest?
a: The south wind.

d: Riddle: what is wisest?
What is wisest?
a: Time.

d: Riddle: what is most general?
What is most general?
a: Hope.

d: Riddle: what is most useful?
What is most useful?
a: Excellence.

d: Riddle: what is most shameful?
What is most shameful?
a: Cowardice.

d: Riddle: what is most pleasant?
What is most pleasant?
a: Love. (In spite of childbirth pains women continue becoming pregnant.)

d: Riddle: what is easiest?
What is easiest?
a: The natural.

d: Riddle: what is the hardest to skin?
What is the hardest to skin?
a: The male member.

d: Who are the best painters?
a: Women  (in the art of make-up).

d: Riddle: what is the best time to eat?
a: For the rich man, when he wishes; for the poor man, when he has something to eat.

d: What are the most accursed things?
What are the most accursed things?
a: A thriftless wife, a baldheaded daughter, a sour-faced daughter-in-law, a crooked axle, and a field which lies across the village road.

d: What is the most difficult to find and the most difficult to lose?
a: The truth.

d: Who are really irresistible?

d: Who are really meek?
a: Cows and daughters.

d: Riddles of distance.

d: Riddle: how deep is the earth (or how far to lower world)?
How deep is the earth?
a: It is deep: my grandfather went into it (died) years ago and has not yet returned.

d: How deep is the earth?

a: Here; if you don't believe it, measure it yourself.

How deep is the sea?

a: So and so high, and if you don't believe it, measure it yourself.

d: How far is it from earth to heaven?
a: As far as you can see.

d: How far is it from earth to heaven?
a: As far as from heaven to earth.

d: How far from earth to heaven?

d: Riddle: seven tongues in a head.
a: (A horse's head in which a bird's nest is found with seven birds in it.)

d: Relationship riddles arising from unusual marriages of relatives.

a: He brings low the proud and exalts the lowly  (said by shepherd masking as bishop to king, who has exchanged places with him).

d: Riddle: drink this wine which a bird took to nest.
a: (Stork took bunch of grapes to nest; boy makes wine from them.)

d: Formerly I was daughter, now I am mother; I have a son who was the husband of my mother.
a: (Girl has nursed her imprisoned father through a crack in the prison wall.)
